Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Analysis of Epigenetic Modifications Regulating Genomic Imprinting in Mouse

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: The majority of genes in mammals are expressed from copies inherited from both the mother and the father, but a small number of genes are only expressed from one of the two copies - these are called imprinted genes. The two parental copies of imprinted genes must be distinguished from each other via an imprinting mark in order to properly control their expression. For some genes, the imprinting mark has been shown to consist of modifications to the DNA and/or to the proteins DNA wraps around in the cell; such modifications are called epigenetic because they affect DNA and chromatin structure but not DNA sequence. This research aims to investigate the acquisition of epigenetic modifications during mammalian development in order to better understand how chromosome structure influences the expression of imprinted genes. One way of addressing this question is by investigating the acquisition of DNA methylation at a specific imprinted gene at different stages of mouse embryonic development. The data obtained will then be compared to the pattern of DNA methylation acquisition at an adjacent gene in order to test the hypothesis that modifications to chromatin structure are coordinately controlled across neighboring regions of the genome. In addition, this research will examine the distribution of modified histone proteins at the imprinted Rasgrf1 gene. Rasgrf1 is expressed solely from the paternal copy in some tissues, but is expressed from both copies in other tissues. Because DNA methylation is associated only with the paternal copy of Rasgrf1, additional epigenetic factors must be responsible for regulating tissue-specific imprinting of this gene. Overall, this research will lend insight into the mechanisms governing the establishment and maintenance of chromatin structure critical for imprinted gene expression.
Broader Impacts: This work will be conducted at Bryn Mawr College, an all-female undergraduate institution with an outstanding record of training young women scientists. Undergraduate students will be the primary researchers involved and will learn to conduct and critically evaluate scientific research under the direct supervision and mentorship of the PI during both the summer and the academic year. Students involved in this project will conduct cutting-edge research in the emerging fields of epigenetics and genomic imprinting, leading to an enhanced educational environment through the use of current methodologies to advance scientific exploration. Students conducting research in the lab will attend weekly lab meetings, present their research to the College community annually, and disseminate their data to the broader scientific community through publication in peer-reviewed journals and presentations at both international scientific conferences and undergraduate research symposia. All of these research-related activities will prepare students for further education or careers in the biological sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For most mammalian genes, the copy inherited from the mother and the copy inherited from the father both contribute to the growth and development of their offspring. However, for a small number of genes, called imprinted genes, only one of the parental copies is functional while the other copy remains silent. The cellular machinery must therefore be able to distinguish between the parental copies and regulate their expression accordingly. Failure to do so results in abnormal growth and development. This research examined how various mechanisms work in concert with each other to achieve the appropriate expression patterns for imprinted genes.

One line of investigation was designed to determine the developmental time at which DNA is chemically modified to achieve the appropriate expression patterns for imprinted genes. The chemical modification analyzed was the addition of a methyl group to the DNA of one parental copy, but not the other; this results in differential DNA methylation of the parental copies which functions both to distinguish them from each other and to regulate their expression such that only one copy is expressed. This work investigated the timing of DNA methylation at a specific imprinted gene, Dlk1, and compared it to data previously determined for a nearby imprinted gene, Gtl2, to determine whether the temporal acquisition of this DNA modification on paternally-inherited DNA is coordinately controlled. Through the course of this work, it was determined that the primary time for DNA methylation acquisition is consistent for these two imprinted genes, although the DNA methylation pattern at Dlk1 remained variable throughout development. The variability in the DNA methylation pattern at Dlk1 was additionally found to correlate with unexpectedly high levels of methylation asymmetry on the complimentary strands of DNA. While methylation symmetry is not typically analyzed at imprinted genes, asymmetry in DNA methylation across the genome is estimated to be 4%, making our observation of 35% asymmetrical methylation at Dlk1 novel. This observation led to the hypothesis that methylation asymmetry may lead to less stable DNA methylation patterns, a theory that will be tested in subsequent research.

A second line of investigation was an analysis of the distribution of modified histones on expressed vs. silent alleles of another imprinted gene, Rasgrf1, to determine if variation in distribution patterns directly correlates with expression. Histones are proteins that DNA wraps around in order to compact it within the cell. Different chemical modifications to the histone proteins can influence how tightly the DNA is compacted, such that less compact regions have higher levels of gene expression and more compact regions have lower levels of gene expression. This work examined which modified histones were present on the methylated and unmethylated copies of a regulatory region associated with Rasgrf1 to determine if the modified histone composition changed in tissues that express Rasgrf1 from one vs. both parental copies. Our findings indicate that the distribution of modified histones correlates with the DNA methylation pattern, rather than the expression status, indicating a direct link between the two different mechanisms responsible for regulating overall chromatin structure. Therefore, changes in Rasgrf1 expression in different tissues does not appear to be driven by changes in the type of modified histones associated with this region.
